User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:7.0a1) Gecko/20110611 Firefox/7.0a1
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:7.0a1) Gecko/20110611 Firefox/7.0a1 ID:20110611030737

I've also heard reports that it runs fine on IE9, although I haven't tested myself.

Tried it on Bas' Azure build, got a similar performance.

kaelan mentioned something about compositing (which this example does, see Engine/js/Rendering.js), but he left before I could ask for more information.

Reproducible: Always

comments.author: bas@basschouten.com
comments.raw_text:
So, presumably this is the globalCompositeOperation listed in http://dl.dropbox.com/u/3590255/Tests/HTML5/007-EntityInteraction/Engine/js/Types/Entity.js. IE9 doesn't support this so that's why presumably it has no issues there (although it doesn't seem to work for me in IE9). It works in IE10 which does support globalCompositeOperation, but there it's slow as well.

I'm not sure why they're using composite operation 'lighter' since this is a solid color and SOURCE-OVER is the same. I can probably optimize something there for Azure at least (probably not worth doing it in cairo at this point).
comments.text:

comments.text:
Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:7.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/7.0
Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:8.0a2) Gecko/20110825 Firefox/8.0a2
Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:9.0a1) Gecko/20110823 Firefox/9.0a1

This bug was tested by several reporters on the Firefox 7 Test day.
I also tested it on FF 7 beta2, latest Aurora and Nightly.

Steps to reproduce:
Make sure your HWA is checked, and load the url in the bug.

Actual results:
FF achieves only max 5fps.

Expected results:
FF should get at least 35+ fps.(Chrome, Opera and Safari achieve 35+ fps)

*Note: On Linux x86 and x86_x64 FF achieves only 10-15 fps max.

raw 'perf' profiler data, xz-compressed

This was captured by the perf profiler with this command:

perf record -f -g -- dist/bin/firefox -P test -no-remote http://dl.dropbox.com/u/3590255/Tests/HTML5/007-EntityInteraction/index.html

comments.text:
Created attachment 556021
plain ASCII-art call-graph from perf profiler, xz-compressed

Just uncompress it with xz, it's a plain text file so it can be read without using perf at all.
comments.raw_text: Just uncompress it with xz, it's a plain text file so it can be read without using perf at all.
comments.creator: jacob.benoit.1@gmail.com
comments.author: jacob.benoit.1@gmail.com

comments.text:
This call graph shows that we spend time mainly in 3 areas:
 * JS engine:
     methodjit-compiled JS code and other JS engine / JSAPI stuff.
     13% time is spent in jitted code, but a lot more is spent in the JS-C++ bridge (XPCWrappedNative etc).
     -> Nothing to say about the JS compiler itself, but maybe we suffer a bit from XPC slowness here.
 * CSS handling:
     nsCSSScanner::Next, Read, ParseNumber, Peek...
     ->Is that normal?
 * Cairo
     lots of time spent in Cairo obviously. A good test would be to check if it's faster in Firefox 7+ on Windows with Azure/Direct2D as that's the only render path we have that doesn't use Cairo.
comments.raw_text:
This call graph shows that we spend time mainly in 3 areas:
 * JS engine:
     methodjit-compiled JS code and other JS engine / JSAPI stuff.
     13% time is spent in jitted code, but a lot more is spent in the JS-C++ bridge (XPCWrappedNative etc).
     -> Nothing to say about the JS compiler itself, but maybe we suffer a bit from XPC slowness here.
 * CSS handling:
     nsCSSScanner::Next, Read, ParseNumber, Peek...
     ->Is that normal?
 * Cairo
     lots of time spent in Cairo obviously. A good test would be to check if it's faster in Firefox 7+ on Windows with Azure/Direct2D as that's the only render path we have that doesn't use Cairo.
comments.creator: jacob.benoit.1@gmail.com
comments.author: jacob.benoit.1@gmail.com

comments.raw_text:
Jeff: please look at the Cairo stuff in the ASCII call graph

Matt: please look at the CSS stuff in the ASCII call graph

Don't know whom to CC about the XPC stuff but I think it's a known problem that we suffer from XPC slowness in canvas demos, see also for WebGL bug 638328.
